abstract.text: Access CloudKit records created from Core Data managed objects.

metadata.title: Reading CloudKit Records for Core Data

inlineContent.text: Although your Core Data app interacts primarily with managed objects, you can access a managed object’s
directly. This is useful if you’re leveraging CloudKit to add features like sharing. You can also use
to access CloudKit records from your web app.
To prevent collision with existing CloudKit record types and reserved names, CloudKit prefixes the
types and fields it creates for your Core Data entities with
To work with records directly, you need to understand the mappings between entities and record types, attributes and fields, and the ways a record stores relationships.
Core Data doesn’t use CloudKit’s native support for relationships,

, because this field limits the number of references to 750, and cannot represent many-to-many relationships. Core Data stores the relationship in CloudKit according to its cardinality (one-to-one, one-to-many, or many-to-many), as described in this article.
CloudKit doesn’t typically support inheritance, so it provides only a single system field,
, to hold type information. Core Data stores the name of the
When you initialize a schema, Core Data adds a custom field to the record type,
, to store the name of the

When you initialize a schema, Core Data creates fields for each of an entity’s attributes, mapping the attribute name to a field with a key in the form
. The field’s type may vary between Core Data and CloudKit.
All variable length attribute types—String, Binary Data, and Transformable—generate an additional field with a key in the form

. If a field’s value grows too large to store within the record size limit of 1MB, Core Data automatically converts the value to an external asset. Core Data transitions between the original field and its asset counterpart transparently during serialization. When inspecting a CloudKit record directly, check the length of the original field’s value; if it is zero, look in the asset field.

One-to-many relationships store a foreign key on each record on the many side of the relationship, mapping the relationship name to a field with a key in the form
. This field stores the foreign key of the related object in the form

content.text: Read Many-to-Many Relationships from CDMR Records

inlineContent.text: Many-to-many relationships model the join table using a custom Core Data Mirrored Relationship (CDMR) record type.

CloudKit doesn’t support the notion of a join, and it’s inefficient to encode arrays on both records and keep them in sync. Instead, Core Data constructs a CDMR record to accurately and succintly capture all of the criteria of the join.
CDMR records have the following fields.
An alphabetically sorted, semicolon-separated list of the entities in the relationship, for example,
. The ordering of this field determines the ordering for all other fields.
The record names of the two related objects, for example,
, sorted according to the CD_entityNames order.
, sorted according to the CD_entityNames order.
For example, consider a many-to-many relationship between
records don’t contain fields for the relationship.
records exists in a third CDMR record. The CDMR record describes the entity type, record name, and Core Data relationship between the

The structure of a CDMR record is carefully designed to occupy the minimum necessary footprint, and to require the least effort to decode and work with, making it usable outside the Core Data framework.

directly through its associated context using

abstract.text: Persist or cache data on a single device, or sync data to multiple devices with CloudKit.
A container that encapsulates the Core Data stack in your app, and mirrors select persistent stores to a CloudKit private database.
Returns the CloudKit record for the specified managed object ID.
Returns the CloudKit record ID for the specified managed object ID.
Returns a dictionary that contains the CloudKit records for the specified managed object IDs.
Design a CloudKit-compatible data model and initialize your CloudKit schema.

abstract.text: An external file that belongs to a record.
A query that describes the criteria to apply when searching for records in a database.
A collection of key-value pairs that store your app’s data.
A relationship between two records in a record zone.
The value that your app defines to identify the type of record.
The value that your app defines to identify the type of record.
Provide access from your web app to your CloudKit app’s containers and databases.
A static byte buffer that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An object for representing and performing arithmetic on base-10 numbers that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An object wrapper for primitive scalar numeric values.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An object representing the location of a resource that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An object representing a universally unique value that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.

value.text: A representation of a specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
An object that represents the location of a resource, such as an item on a remote server or the path to a local file.
An object for representing and performing arithmetic on base-10 numbers.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object.
A static byte buffer in memory.
A universally unique value that can be used to identify types, interfaces, and other items.
